awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Recovering Ergativity in Heritage Samoan
awd_abstract_narration:
Human languages can be split into two groups based upon how they mark the grammatical subject and object in a sentence. Accusative languages like English, Spanish and Japanese mark subjects distinctly from objects; ergative languages like Kaqchikel, Inuktitut and Samoan mark the direct object of a transitive verb in the same way as the subject of an intransitive verb. Ergativity is thought to be a fragile feature of language since ergative languages may lose their ergative marking and become accusative languages, but accusative languages rarely become ergative. This shift occurs because children acquire ergativity quite late in childhood, making ergativity susceptible to loss. Second language (L2) learners have great difficulty with it, and heritage speakers whose childhood home language is ergative have particular difficulty with ergativity if the dominant societal language is accusative. Thus many ergative languages are in danger of losing this defining characteristic. This dissertation project investigates how ergativity might be strengthened in the minds of heritage Samoan speakers by presenting them with a targeted protocol designed to increase their knowledge of ergativity. This project contributes to our understanding of an important though understudied property of human language, ergativity, as well as a large (and understudied) learning population, namely heritage speakers. It also furthers our understanding of an important language of the Pacific: Samoan. The research protocol and results will have important implications for language pedagogy that target languages with fragile grammatical features such as ergativity.

The experiments will be conducted by Grant Muagututiʻa, a doctoral student at the University of Hawaii, and will involve three groups of learners (native, heritage, L2) in a series of experiments targeting morphological ergativity (case) and syntactic ergativity (relative clauses, wh-questions) in both comprehension and production. The durability of the recovered ergativity is tested by increasing the length of time between instruction and testing. Comparing L2 speakers and heritage speakers addresses whether the increase in ergativity is attributable to knowledge gained as (heritage) children, while testing case, relativization and wh-questions addresses whether morphological ergativity transfers to syntactic ergativity.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated a population of speakers referred to as heritage language learners. Such learners are exposed to a language in childhood that is different from that of the society (typically a language that has a heritage conenction to their family). This exposure to the heritage language stops when children enter school. The question addressed here is whether there are any remaining effects of that early childhood exposure in adults who are trying to relearn their heritage language.

The project tested heritage Samoan participants (those who were exposed to Samoan as children, but then English took over, and they are now trying to learn Samoan as adults) on an abstract grammatical pattern (referred to as ergativity), finding that learners had no knowledge of these patterns at the outset of the study. The learners were then given an intervention (where they were exposed to the abstract pattern in question), and the learners were then tested again. The findings were that learners showed a significant increase in knowledge of ergativity after the intervention. More interestingly, they transfered that kwnoledge to patterns that they never heard before, and they retained this knwoledge in subsequent test periods weeks later.

Adults who had no childhood exposure to Samoan who were learning Samoan as a second language were also tested in the same way, and a much weaker effect of intervention was found. Moreover, second language learners of Samoan did not transfer this weak increase of knowledge of ergativty to patterns they were not exposed to. This shows that heritage learners did indeed have some remnant of their childhood exposure within them, and this helped them acquire the abstract grammatical pattern that they were exposed to. 

The Intellectual Merit of this project is that it reveals the difference between heritage and regular second language learners. It also reveals how in the minds of heritage speakers, different ergative patterns are linked, while in the minds of regular second language learners, such patterns seem to be independent constructions.

The Broader Impacts of this study are significant. The development of an intervention protocol for the teaching of ergativity is something that could be used in many understudied and less commonly taught languages. Secondly, the results of this study suggest that institutions that teach languages of immigrant communities in the USA should consider splitting heritage and second language populations into two distinct groups, since they come into the classroom with different base knowledge, and therefore will require different kinds of instruction and curricula.
